author: tersec
content: As a procedural matter: https://forkcast.org/upgrade/glamsterdam/ doesn't contain EIP-8071 but https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-7773#proposed-for-inclusion does have it. Presumably Forkcast is delayed, but EIP-7773 is canonical?

author: tersec
content: Question about EIP-8062: forkcast says it "Improves fairness between legacy 0x01 and compounding 0x02 validators". What does that even mean?

author: tersec
content: What does "Aligns CL withdrawals with EL resource usage." mean?

author: tersec
content: And in particular, to the extent it "Incentivizes operators to consolidate for the benefit of the network", it seems like that's in some tension with the idea of "improving fairness", based on the usual definitions I see used of fairness. It's explicitly biasing outcomes. Good, bad, worthwhile, not worthwhile, that's not really about "fairness", it's about engineering incentives

author: tersec
content: For EIP-8061: "while preserving a long weak-subjectivity period and existing security assumptions." is just, straightforwardly, not consistent with the EIP. https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-8061#weak-subjectivity-period notes it decreases the WSP from about 16 days to somewhere between 7-10 days

author: nero_eth
content: Every withdrawal comes with data in the block + a state diff on the EL. This requires loading the account of the wd recipient from disk, write to it, and update the post state root. Right now the EL charges nothing for that, although withdrawals do consume EL resources.

author: nero_eth
content: It's cleaner to have the CL deduct that fee already such that the EL doesn't need to care about it or change anything in it's wd-processing logic. It's possible to just deduct e.g. the fee for creating a new account on the EL but less clean than doing it at the CL.
